journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: A finite element investigation on plaque vulnerability in realistic healthy and atherosclerotic human coronary arteries

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran
2Tissue Engineering and Biomaterials Division, National Institute of Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology, Tehran, Iran
3Department of Ophthalmology, Baqiyatallah University of Medical Sciences, Tehran, Iran
4Department of Biomechanics, Science and Research Branch, Islamic Azad University, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Kamran Hassani, Department of Biomedical Engineering, Science and Research Branch, Islamic Azad University, Golzare 1, Adl blvd, Poonak, Tehran, 755/4515 Iran. Email: k.hasani@srbiau.ac.ir

abstract.p: Atherosclerosis is the most common arterial disease. It has been shown that stresses that are induced during blood circulation can cause plaque rupture and, in turn, lead to thrombosis and stroke. In this study, finite element method is used to predict plaque vulnerability based on peak plaque stress using human samples. A total of 23 healthy and atherosclerotic human coronary arteries of 14 healthy and 9 atherosclerotic patients are excised within 5 h postmortem. The samples are mounted on an uniaxial tensile test machine, and the obtained mechanical properties are used in two-dimensional and three-dimensional finite element models. The results including the Neo–Hookean hyperelastic coefficients of the samples as well as peak plaque stresses are analyzed. The results indicate that the atherosclerotic human coronary arteries have significantly (p < 0.05) higher stiffness compared with the healthy ones. The hypocellular plaque also has the highest stress values and, as a result, is most likely (vulnerable) to rupture, while the calcified type has the lowest stress values and, consequently, is expected to remain stable. The results could be used in the plaque vulnerability anticipation and have clinical implications in interventions and surgeries, including balloon angioplasty, bypass, and stenting.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is the most common arterial wall disease that is responsible for approximately 30% of all mortalities worldwide.1–3 The atherosclerotic lesion partially or totally blocks the lumen and decreases the blood supply, leading to thickening of the arterial wall,4,5 which, in turn, causes the alteration of mechanical properties.6,7 On one hand, atherosclerosis has two mechanisms of vascular changes: morphological thickening and functional stiffening of arterial wall.8 The arterial wall stiffening involves atherosclerotic lesion development, during which the diseased coronary segment becomes progressively stiffer.9,10 On the other hand, a concentration of circumferential tensile stress that is induced by the blood pressure in a certain portion of the plaque surface can cause plaque rupture followed by thrombosis and stroke, which also happen without warning most of the time.11–13 The plaque with highest stress value is defined as a vulnerable plaque;12 therefore, it is most likely (vulnerable) to rupture. In the present study, the same definition is used regarding the plaque vulnerability. Hence, plaque vulnerability is another facet that is defined when the stress on plaque decreases the strength of its material and then causes plaque rupture consequently.14–16 Most studies regarding the plaque rupture analysis have been concerned with in vivo magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)-based two-dimensional (2D)/three-dimensional (3D) multicomponent models with fluid–structure interactions.13,17–19 In these studies, the results of MRI images were used to compute the critical stress on plaques and then to characterize the plaque that is most likely to rupture—vulnerable plaque.

Most atherosclerotic plaques, nevertheless, remain stable and thus can bear more stress on its area, while vulnerable plaques cannot experience stress on and are very likely to rupture. Therefore, discrimination between stable and unstable vulnerable plaques has pivotal role in the atherosclerotic studies.20 Mechanical properties of the artery wall are a matter of great importance to plaque rupture study. There are some studies on the mechanical properties of human coronary arteries, but most of them have been carried out almost exclusively on animals.21–24 The mechanical properties, which have been found for the animals’ coronary arteries, are bounded values and can be only used for an approximate estimation and comparative assessment of the similar parameters in human.15,25 Moreover, atherosclerosis in humans is a multifactorial disease and its simplified animal models are unreliable.15 Holzapfel et al.26 used 13 nonstenotic human left anterior descending coronary arteries. His study tried to compute the stress–stretch responses for the different layers of the human coronary tissues. The biaxial mechanical properties of human coronary and carotid arteries have been measured for computational modeling.6 Also, the planar biaxial mechanical properties of coronary artery, using in vivo patient-specific predictive model, have been used to assess the plaque vulnerability.27 In the present study, however, an in vitro uniaxial tensile test method was used to characterize the mechanical properties of human coronary arteries.

There are also many applications in medical research and engineering that would require proper knowledge of mechanical properties of the coronary arterial wall. This will include the design and fabrication of new generation of cardiovascular prosthesis,2,28 artificial arteries29 as well as finite element (FE) analysis,21 simulation of blood flow, development of a patient-specific predictive model, therapy planning, and diagnosis and treatment of cardiovascular diseases.29 It is also essential to understand the rupture mechanism and to predict cardiovascular events.3 It is therefore vital to define an experimental setup to characterize the human mechanical behavior of coronary arteries in order to assess the plaque vulnerability. The plaque vulnerability assessment, however, is difficult to study directly in humans;15 thus, FE analysis can be used to calculate the peak plaque stress. For this study, 23 human coronary arteries including 9 atherosclerotic and 14 healthy arteries were excised within 5 h postmortem. These human coronary arteries were mounted on a uniaxial tensile test machine, and the Neo–Hookean hyperelastic coefficients based on the obtained stress–strain diagrams were calculated. The digital image correlation (DIC) technique is used to measure the displacement. The DIC is an optical, thus contactless, method to determine the displacement and strain. The principle of DIC is to assess the displacement fields, and hence, strain fields over the surface of a deforming material by comparison of two images obtained at different stages of the deformation. The first image is referred to as the reference image, and the second image, acquired after some increment of deformation, is referred to as the deformed image. In general, the method starts by defining a grid of analysis points over the reference image; then a group of pixels, commonly named as subset, is defined about each node of this grid. The image correlation is performed, for each node, by identifying the most similar subset in the deformed image based on some statistical measurement of correlation of the images within each subset.30 Finally, the 2D and 3D FE models were used in order to investigate the plaque vulnerability and compute the peak plaque stresses comprehensively.

sec.title: Experimental humans and surgical procedures
sec.p: The coronary arteries were removed during autopsy within 5 h postmortem from 23 male individuals. The arteries were removed from the vascular bed under the epicardium and cleaned from the surrounding tissue subsequently. In order to minimize tissue degradation, portions of the coronary arteries were immediately preserved in ion-free phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) (0.9% NaCl) at 4°C–5°C before the performance of the uniaxial test. The testing material was obtained by cutting the 40- to 65-mm-long branchless segments of the coronary arteries from the proximal and distal parts. The healthy and atherosclerotic individuals have a mean ± standard deviation (SD) of 38.07 ± 8.58 and 67.22 ± 10.96 years, respectively. The use of autopsy material from human subjects was approved by the Ethics Committee of the Legal Medicine Organization.

sec.title: Experimental setting and tensile testing
sec.p: The outer diameter, earliest wall thickness, and length of the segments of coronary arteries were measured precisely. The tensile test was performed using a uniaxial tensile apparatus adapted for testing soft tissues and biological specimens, as shown schematically in Figure 1. A combination of DIC31,32 and absolute digital caliper was used to compute the strain. The tensile machine was equipped with an optical microscope (Olympus CX-21, Olysia software, UC30 high-speed 3MPixel camera, Tokyo, Japan) having an accuracy of 0.025 mm ± 0.05%, and an Insize absolute digital caliper (Vienna, Austria; 0.005 mm ± 0.05%) was used to measure the displacement of the platens during the tensile tests. The field of view was set to an area of approximately 15 mm × 15 mm comprising the entire width, centered on the right movable jaw. The acquisition frequency was 15 images per second. The force was measured with a 50-N load cell (Digital push/pull force gauge ISF-DF50, Insize) having a minimal resolution of 0.01 N ± 0.5%. All tests were conducted at a temperature of 37°C. Each sample was tested only once. An axial motion servo motor was used for the motion of movable jaw with strain rate of 1 mm/min. The experiments that were conducted in this study were designed to give more insight into the tissue behavior at lower strains and strain rates, which are typical for surgical procedures.33 Right before the test, the human coronary samples were taken out from the physiological saline and mounted on the tensile test machine. The tensile test was carried out at sufficient extra relative humidity to prevent the specimens to be drought. To do this, the specimen was consistently kept wet by a spray of physiological saline. Each coronary artery was placed and fixed between the jaws by applying small tensile preload (0.05 N) to ensure a reliable contact of the sample between the left fix jaw and right movable jaw of the test machine. The preload was chosen based on the artery tissue stiffness. Then the sample length was measured. The preload also helped to minimize the bending effect caused by the weight of each specimen. The force was applied to each specimen until the failure occurred, and the stress–strain diagrams of healthy and atherosclerotic human coronary arteries were obtained.

caption.p: Schematic of the uniaxial tensile test machine.

sec.title: Stress–strain analysis
sec.p: The walls of coronary arteries were assumed as incompressible material to let us calculate the true stress–strain diagram.34,35 To calculate the true stress and strain, we need to define engineering stress and strain, which depends on the earliest dimensions of the artery. The engineering stress is calculated by
where F is the load and A0 is the initial cross-sectional area.
The engineering strain is
where λ is the stretch and L0 is the earliest length. Then, we describe the true stress
where A is the current cross-sectional area. The true strain is defined as
where dL is the variable stretch and L is the current length of the specimen. The hypothetical incompressibility of the coronary artery indicates a zero change of volume during the tensile testing
and then
The true strain is defined as the sum of all the current engineering strains. Thus
Considering these equations, the true stress–strain curves can be computed.

sec.title: Model description
sec.p: The mechanical behavior of the artery wall was assumed to be homogenous, isotropic, incompressible, and nonlinear based on the available literature.2,14,36,37 The Neo–Hookean hyperelastic constitutive equation is widely accepted to describe the hyperelastic material behavior, especially arteries.14,38,39 Therefore, a hyperelastic Neo–Hookean model was used to model both the coronary artery wall and plaque materials.40

where W is the strain energy per unit reference volume for the hyperelastic material, I¯1 is the first deviatoric strain invariant, d is the material incompressibility parameter, j is the determinant of the elastic deformation gradient, and µ is the initial shear modulus.
The initial bulk modulus is related to the material incompressibility parameter by

The hyperelastic constants for the healthy and atherosclerotic coronary arteries that were obtained from the experimental test on human coronary arteries and three types of plaque (calcified, hypocellular, and cellular)2 are displayed in Table 1.

caption.p: Neo–Hookean hyperelastic coefficients for the artery/plaque models.

sec.title: 3D model
sec.p: The coronary artery was modeled as a hollow cylinder with an internal diameter of 3 mm, a thickness of 1 mm, and a length of 20 mm. The artery dimension in FE modeling was obtained from the removed artery segments.

Luminal stenosis has been used traditionally to indicate the severity of the atherosclerotic disease;41 so, in this study, based on plaque severity, the 70%, 80%, and 90% area of stenosis have been chosen.42

The coronary artery and plaque were modeled by eight-node linear brick and reduced integration elements including six degrees of freedom at each node (C3D8RH). The artery and plaque geometries consisted of 10158, 16496, and 16356 elements as well as 23934, 37916, and 37228 nodes for the 70%, 80%, and 90% area of stenosis, respectively. The mesh resolution was determined in the Neo–Hookean model based on a mesh density study.

sec.title: 2D model
sec.p: The coronary artery was modeled as an idealized circle with an internal diameter of 3 mm and thickness of 1 mm based on the geometry of coronary arteries. The plaque dimensions were obtained from the histology image of atherosclerotic human coronary artery.

The coronary artery and plaque were modeled by a four-node bilinear plane stress and quadrilateral reduced integration elements (CPS4R). The artery and plaque geometries were discretized by 3815, 4148, and 4465 elements as well as 4034, 4349, and 4652 nodes for the 70%, 80%, and 90% area of stenosis, respectively. The mesh resolution was also determined on the basis of a mesh density study.

sec.title: Boundary conditions
sec.p: The two sides of artery walls were fully constrained in the axial direction. Also, the rotations about all axes, both the distal and proximal ends, were fixed. In 2D model, the outer diameter of the artery wall was also fully constrained. A pressure of 100 mm Hg was applied on the interior of the artery wall.11,16 The average predicted von Mises stresses as well as the first principal component stress of each element, both for the arterial tissues and the plaque tissues, were computed.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The data were first analyzed using analysis of variance (ANOVA). After finding the statistical differences, we performed the student’s t test to compare among the groups using SPSS software version 16.0 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA). The data are reported as mean ± SD at a significance level of p < 0.05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The arteries and their position on uniaxial tensile test are displayed in Figure 2. The stress–strain diagrams for healthy and atherosclerotic arteries are shown in Figure 3. The histology image of plaque severity in the atherosclerotic artery is presented in Figure 4.

caption.p: Coronary artery segments (a) before testing, (b) during the tensile test, and (c) after failing.
True stress–strain diagram for the (a) healthy and (b) atherosclerotic human coronary arteries.
Histology image of the atherosclerotic plaque that was used for two-dimensional finite element models.

sec.p: Regarding the stress–strain diagram, the atherosclerotic human coronary arteries showed significantly lower mean extensibility compared with the healthy human coronary arteries. The maximum stress of healthy human coronary arteries was 1.44 ± 0.87 and 2.08 ± 0.86 MPa, while the maximum strain was 0.54 ± 0.25 and 0.35 ± 0.11.

sec.title: 3D model
sec.p: The three-dimensional FE models are demonstrated in Figures 5 to 7 for the 70%, 80%, and 90% area of stenosis, respectively. The hypocellular plaque has the highest plaque stress compared with the cellular and calcified types equal to 123.20, 115.20, and 110.50 kPa for the 70%, 80%, and 90% area of stenosis, respectively. In contrast to the hypocellular plaque, calcified plaque has the lowest stress values of 52.52, 50.54, and 51.26 kPa for the 70%, 80%, and 90% area of stenosis, respectively. Figures 8 to 10 show the first principal component stress for the 70%, 80%, and 90% area of stenosis, respectively. The hypocellular plaque has the highest stress values of 66.59, 64.89, and 62.79 kPa for the 70%, 80%, and 90% area of stenosis, respectively. The calcified plaque, however, has the lowest stress values of 28.97, 27.93, and 27.04 kPa for the 70%, 80%, and 90% area of stenosis, respectively.

caption.p: Three-dimensional peak plaques stress for the 70% area of stenosis: (a) same material, (b) calcified, (c) cellular, and (d) hypocellular plaque.

Three-dimensional first principal plaques stress for the 90% area of stenosis: (a) same material, (b) calcified, (c) cellular, and (d) hypocellular plaque.

sec.title: 2D model
sec.p: The 2D FE models are demonstrated in Figures 11 to 13 for the 70%, 80%, and 90% area of stenosis, respectively. The hypocellular plaque has the highest plaque stress compared with the cellular and calcified types with 77.38, 27.68, and 26.28 kPa for the 70%, 80%, and 90% area of stenosis, respectively. The first principal component stress for the 70%, 80%, and 90% area of stenosis is shown in Figures 14 to 16, respectively. The hypocellular plaque has the highest stress with 40.75, 15.87, and 15.04 kPa for the 70%, 80%, and 90% area of stenosis, respectively. The calcified plaque, however, has the lowest stress values of 33.80, 8.70, and 9.652 kPa for the 70%, 80%, and 90% area of stenosis, respectively.

caption.p: Two-dimensional peak plaques stress for the 70% area of stenosis: (a) same material, (b) calcified, (c) cellular, and (d) hypocellular plaque.
Two-dimensional peak plaques stress for the 80% area of stenosis: (a) same material, (b) calcified, (c) cellular, and (d) hypocellular plaque.
Two-dimensional peak plaques stress for the 90% area of stenosis: (a) same material, (b) calcified, (c) cellular, and (d) hypocellular plaque.
Two-dimensional first principal plaques stress for the 70% area of stenosis: (a) same material, (b) calcified, (c) cellular, and (d) hypocellular plaque.
Two-dimensional first principal plaques stress for the 80% area of stenosis: (a) same material, (b) calcified, (c) cellular, and (d) hypocellular plaque.
Two-dimensional first principal plaques stress for the 70% area of stenosis: (a) same material, (b) calcified, (c) cellular, and (d) hypocellular plaque.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Experimental method is a useful tool to study physiological and failure mechanics of soft tissues.43 Most investigations regarding the mechanical properties of the coronary arteries have been performed on animals due to the lack of human testing materials.6,44 The purpose of this study was to determine the mechanical properties of the healthy and atherosclerotic human coronary arteries. Then, FE model was used to predict the plaque rupture–plaque vulnerability based on the peak plaque stress.

Previous studies in terms of stress–strain diagram have indicated that atherosclerotic human coronary tissues displayed nonlinear behavior. Furthermore, the Hookean part of the stress–strain diagram for both the strain and stress was increased proportionally. However, in higher amount of stress, there is a minor increase in the amount of strain.3 This is inconsistent with our results, which show that the atherosclerotic human coronary arteries can experience 44.55% more stress and 34.61% less strain compared with the healthy coronary arteries (Figure 3).45,46 In addition, morbidity of coronary artery is believed to be related to the magnitudes of stress and strain within the arteries, and thus, quantification of these values is of great importance.6,45 Stress is the principal biomechanical quantity. Since it has been reported that plaque rupture occurs when the imposed circumferential stress on the plaque exceeds its tensile strength.20 It is also widely accepted that plaque is most vulnerable in areas where stresses are concentrated, such as shoulders, which are considered as the most acute locations for rupture initiation.12,41 The results also indicated that the highest stresses in all three percent areas of stenosis (70%, 80%, and 90%) considered in this study were located in the artery wall with hypocellular plaque, while the stiffer calcified plaque appeared to play a protective role. This is in good agreement with the study by Pericevic et al.,2 which has shown that higher pressures can be applied to calcified plaque with a lower risk of arterial vascular injury. Thus, the calcified plaque with the lowest peak plaque stress is considered as the most stable plaque compared with other two plaque types. The results have also shown that when the area of stenosis increased, the peak plaque stresses in all three types of plaque decreased accordingly. This is also in agreement with the study by Imoto et al.,22 which has depicted that increasing plaque volume results in increase in thickness of the wall and decrease in luminal diameter, leading to a decrease in the surface stress of the plaque. Hence, the hypocellular plaque is the vulnerable plaque in comparison with cellular and calcified types. It is worthwhile to know that despite the differences between the peak plaque stresses on three types of plaques, all plaques were equally vulnerable.16

It should be noted that the mechanical properties of arteries that have been reported so far mostly concern with animals; so, understanding the mechanical properties of the human arteries has key asset in plaque rupture study as well as FE modeling.

There are also many applications in medical research and engineering that would require appropriate knowledge of the mechanical properties of the coronary arterial wall. This will consist of the design of devices that usually involves numerical techniques, which need the important mechanical properties of the arteries.47 The mechanical properties of arteries also play a crucial role in plaque fracture mechanics, which are still not fully understood.16 Hence, it is important to define an experimental setup to characterize the mechanical behavior of human arteries in order to improve computational models that assess plaque vulnerability.3

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: In this study, plaque rupture was assumed as a mechanical structure rather than a biological one. Apparently, plaque rupture is a dynamic biological, biochemical, and biomechanical process, and only one aspect of this complex interaction was considered and computed in this study.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Heart diseases such as atherosclerosis continue to be the leading cause of morbidity and mortality not only in industrialized countries but also in undeveloped countries. Moreover, in fact, to develop the treatment techniques, the comprehensive knowledge of arteries is really needed. Plaque that is induced inside the artery wall can reduce the lumen of arteries and can also rupture during the blood circulation. Circumferential stress is one of the main roots of plaque rupturing, which is induced as a result of blood circulation. However, it leads to stress concentration on plaque area and causes rupturing followed by thrombosis and stroke. So far due to lack of study on mechanical properties of human coronary arteries, plaque vulnerability investigation has been mostly conducted on animal models. Thus, this study had aimed to characterize the mechanical properties of human coronary arteries and then assess the plaque vulnerability based on peak plaque stress with proper data using FE model. The results have shown that the hypocellular plaque is very likely to rupture, while the calcified plaque is expected to remain stable and, hence, can bear more stress on its area. Our understanding is that there is a relation between high stress and plaque vulnerability, and the relation should be considered as a risk factor, but we aim to do further studies to determine a threshold value for critical stress as guidance to assess plaque vulnerability in the future. Furthermore, stress is only one way to assess vulnerability, and plaque rupture may be caused by other factors that have to be studied. Moreover, the results could have implication in vascular surgery, including balloon angioplasty, bypass, and stenting. The hyperelastic coefficients that were obtained in this study could be used in the design of new vascular synthetic or biological prostheses with appropriate mechanical properties for the field of tissue engineering.

ack.p: The authors acknowledge all the help and support of their colleagues at the Iran University of Science and Technology, National Institute of Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology, and Iranian Legal Medicine Organization, especially Dr Alireza Kadkhodaei. Individual contributions are as follows: AK prepared samples for testing, created the finite element modeling based on the obtained stress–strain diagram, interpreted the primary data, and performed the various simulations required. AS helped to analyze the results and drafted the article. MN, SF, and KH were involved in the supervision and development of the research. KH revised the article. All the authors approved the final version of the article.
